C1_Notes: On March 15, 2020, the Kenyan government decided to shut down schools and colleges nationwide in response to COVID-19, affecting nearly 17 million students countrywide. https://web.archive.org/web/20200607144515/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/coronavirus-kenya-shuts-schools-as-new-cases-confirmed/1767139 http://web.archive.org/web/20200824023446/https://www.brookings.edu/blog/education-plus-development/2020/05/06/how-school-closures-during-covid-19-further-marginalize-vulnerable-children-in-kenya/
C2_Notes: Work closing is recommended but not required. However, closing is required to meet the curfew hours. https://web.archive.org/web/20200406110459/https://www.president.go.ke/2020/03/15/address-to-the-nation-by-h-e-uhuru-kenyatta-c-g-h-president-of-the-republic-of-kenya-and-commander-in-chief-of-the-defence-forces-on-covid-19-commonly-known-as-coronavirus/
H1_Notes: On media channels and through government-sponsored adverts https://web.archive.org/web/20200406111753/http://www.health.go.ke/

E1_Notes: Direct cash payments to vulnerable citizens bolstered, "additional Ksh. 10 Billion to the elderly, orphans and other vulnerable members of our society through cash-transfers by the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection, to cushion them from the adverse economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic" https://web.archive.org/web/20200428114436/https://www.president.go.ke/2020/03/25/presidential-address-on-the-state-interventions-to-cushion-kenyans-against-economic-effects-of-covid-19-pandemic-on-25th-march-2020/
E3_Notes: Suite of measures announced, no clear single figure/value -- All proposals can only be ratified by the National Assembly, and the National Treasury Cabinet Secretary Ukur Yatani has been directed to present them before Parliament for approval before April 1, 2020. List of what was announced below, including tax reliefs and measures to help reduce financial uncertainty among Kenyans: >100% tax relief to Kenyans earning Ksh24, 000 and below. >Pay as you earn (PAYE) reduction from a maximum of 30% to 25%. >Reduction of turnover tax rate from 3% to 1% for all micro, small and medium enterprises. >Reduction of resident income tax to 25%. >The Government to make available Ksh10 billion to vulnerable groups including the elderly and orphans, among others. This, the president, said will be done through cash transfers from the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection. >Temporary suspension of the listing of loan defaulters with the Credit Reference Bureau (CRB) of any person, micro, small and medium enterprise and corporate entities whose loan account is in arrears effective April 1, 2020. >Reduction of VAT from 16% to 14% effective April 1, 2020. >All ministries and State departments to make payments amounting to Ksh30 billion to those owed monies by the Government. This, the president said, must be done within three weeks from March 25. The Head of State also urged the private sector to clear pending bills. >KRA to expedite payment of all VAT refunds amounting to Ksh10 billion, or allow withholding of offsetting VAT. This, President Kenyatta said, must happen within three weeks. >The president and his deputy to take 80% pay-cut, all Cabinet Secretaries to take 30% pay-cuts, Chief Administrative Secretaries (30%) and Principal Secretaries (20%). >All State and public officers aged 50 and above; and have preexisting medical conditions, to take leave from work, or be allowed to work from home. This directive excludes those public officers working in the security department. >Reduce the Cash Reserve Ratio from 5.25% to 4.25%. The president said this will help increase liquidity of Ksh35 billion to commercial banks, which, in turn, will be in positions to provide loan services to â€œdistressed Kenyansâ€. >CBK directed to provide flexibility to bank loan classifications and loans performing as at March 2, 2020.

The National Treasury implemented the following immediate reliefs and increase disposable income to the people of Kenya, through: I. 100 % Tax Relief for persons earning gross monthly income of up to Ksh. 24,000. II. Reduction of Income Tax Rate (Pay-As-You-Earn) from 30% to 25%. III. Reduction of Resident Income Tax (Corporation Tax) from 30% to 25%; IV. Reduction of the turnover tax rate from the current 3% to 1% for all Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs); V. Appropriation of an additional Ksh. 10 Billion to the elderly, orphans and other vulnerable members of our society through cash-transfers by the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection, to cushion them from the adverse economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic; VI. Temporary suspension of the listing with Credit Reference Bureaus (CRB) of any person, Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMES) and corporate entities whose loan account fall overdue or is in arrears, effective 1st April, 2020. https://web.archive.org/web/20200406120050/https://www.president.go.ke/2020/03/25/presidential-address-on-the-state-interventions-to-cushion-kenyans-against-economic-effects-of-covid-19-pandemic-on-25th-march-2020/

C5_Notes: As part of the "Restriction of Movement of Persons and Related Measures" announced on 6 April, travel is prohibited between areas deemed as "infected" and "not infected" between 8-29 April. However, public transport can still operate within an "infected" area during this period provided compliance with health protocols and reduced capacity (see pages 656-657). https://web.archive.org/web/20200702130154/https://kam.co.ke/kam/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/L.-N.-No.-50-Public-Health-Amended-LEGAL-VERSION.pdf.pdf
C6_Notes: 21 day movement ban in effect for Nairobi, Kilifi, Kwale and Mombasa everyone else under curfew and advised to stay indoors. https://archive.fo/wip/CvAbp
E3_Notes: The National Treasury was directed by the President Uhuru Kenyatta to use Sh2 billion (USD 18.78M) which are proceeds collected from the corrupt to help the vulnerable people in the society. https://web.archive.org/web/20200414005133/https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/2020/04/odpp-channels-sh2-billion-graft-proceeds-to-covid-19-emergency-response-fund/

C6_Notes: On 25 April, the President of Kenya announced an extension of the existing lockdown measures in the regions of Nairobi, Mombassa, Kilifi, and Kwale. The quarantine will be extended by 21 days as these areas are most at-risk for the virus. http://web.archive.org/web/20200824045521/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-25/kenya-shuts-off-capital-for-3-more-weeks-tax-changes-approved

E3_Notes: On May 23, President Uhuru Kenyatta announced a Sh53.7 billion Economic Stimulus Package (ESP 2). This came a few weeks after he announced a raft of tax and expenditure measures to cushion the economy from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, his first ESP as president. https://web.archive.org/web/20200702132346/https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/analysis/ideas/Kenya-economic-stimulus-package-2-will-fall-far-short/4259414-5568156-11sjosb/index.html

C2_Notes: On 6 June, the President announced a 30-day extension of the measure that orders bars to remain closed. http://web.archive.org/web/20200824025132/https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/2020/06/uhuru-orders-bars-to-remain-closed-for-30-more-days/
C3_Notes: As part of the measures announced on 6 June, all forms of gatherings, including political meetings, will remain banned for at least 30 more days. http://web.archive.org/web/20200824025132/https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/2020/06/uhuru-orders-bars-to-remain-closed-for-30-more-days/
C4_Notes: As part of the measures announced on 6 June, all forms of gatherings, including political meetings, will remain banned for at least 30 more days. http://web.archive.org/web/20200824025132/https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/2020/06/uhuru-orders-bars-to-remain-closed-for-30-more-days/
C6_Notes: On 6 June, the Government announced an ease in the movement restrictions in some areas of Nairobi as well as Mombasa's Old Town and the counties of Kilifi and Kwale. However, lockdown measures will remain in place until 6 July in most of Nairobi's Metropolitan area, and the Mombasa and Mandera counties. http://web.archive.org/web/20200824051723/https://nairobinews.nation.co.ke/featured/uhuru-extends-nairobi-mombasa-lockdown-by-30-days http://web.archive.org/web/20200824044618/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/348946/kenya-authorities-announce-extension-of-lockdown-measures-until-july-6-update-23
C7_Notes: On 6 June, Kenyan President announced an extension of the nationwide lockdown measures until July 6. Restrictions on road, rail, and air movements in and out of the Nairobi Metropolitan area, as well as Mombasa and Mandera counties were also extended for 30 days. http://web.archive.org/web/20200824044618/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/348946/kenya-authorities-announce-extension-of-lockdown-measures-until-july-6-update-23
H2_Notes: The government continues to increase capacity for testing and managing cases. Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210524161315/https://www.health.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/UPDATE-ON-CORONAVIRUS-6TH-JUNE-2020.pdf
H4_Notes: The president mentioned in his address on the 6th of June 2020 that 5 billion Kenyan Shillings (46,668,000 USD via OANDA currency converter) was disbursed to counties. Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210529134328/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/6296484028th%20presidential.pdf

C1_Notes: The Education Ministry is expected to start gradual reopening of schools from September 1 while a new learning calendar should be ready by Mid-August 2020. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210523110915/https://allafrica.com/stories/202006160079.html
C2_Notes: The restrictions put in place include a partial lockdown in Nairobi and the coastal city of Mombasa and a nationwide dusk-to-dawn curfew. Some businesses like bars and schools and places of worship remain shut as passenger vehicles carry half their capacity to curb the spread of the disease. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210523112011/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-06/29/c_139175561.htm
C3_Notes: President Kenyatta on June 6 extended a ban on public gatherings for 30 days to curb the spread of coronavirus, restricting entry and exit from the capital and the counties of Mombasa and Mandera for a similar period. https://web.archive.org/web/20200702125137/https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/news/Governors-want-economy-reopened-
C4_Notes: No specific mention of gathering size, but I think a 4G is reasonable approximation given severity of other restrictions. President Kenyatta on June 6 extended a ban on public gatherings for 30 days to curb the spread of coronavirus, restricting entry and exit from the capital and the counties of Mombasa and Mandera for a similar period. https://web.archive.org/web/20200702125137/https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/news/Governors-want-economy-reopened-
C6_Notes: The lockdown was extended for 30 days in Nairobi, Mombasa and Mandera as well as the nationwide curfew by 30 days .The president, however, said that the current curfew hours which were between 7pm-5am will now be from 9pm-4am beginning tomorrow June 7.according to the president. Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20200824051723if_/https://nairobinews.nation.co.ke/featured/uhuru-extends-nairobi-mombasa-lockdown-by-30-days
C7_Notes: On June 6, the Government of Kenya (GoK) announced that movement restrictions in and out of Nairobiâ€™s Eastleigh neighborhood, Mombasaâ€™s Old Town neighborhood, and the counties of Kilifi and Kwale lapse as of June 7. However, movement restrictions in and out of the Nairobi Metropolitan Area, Mombasa and Mandera counties are extended an additional 30 days. https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.osac.gov/Country/Kenya/Content/Detail/Report/eb77c55d-fbca-4670-9c2d-18e154a19666
C8_Notes: Per the June 6 announcement, the GoK continued restrictions of international flights in and out of Kenya. The Kenyan Ministry of Transport will develop protocols to reinstate domestic air travel. https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.osac.gov/Country/Kenya/Content/Detail/Report/eb77c55d-fbca-4670-9c2d-18e154a19666
E1_Notes: Recoded (previous coder had changed from 1F and then to 2F without sourcing). Appears that Kenya is still offering direct cash payments at less than 50% average income to people including formal and informal workers, vulnerable persons or families, etc. http://web.archive.org/web/20200718161903/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/kenya-tax-developments-in-response-to-covid-19.html
H1_Notes: The Ministry of Health has an active page with information on the virus and public health guidelines. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20200406111753/http://www.health.go.ke/

C1_Notes: On 7 July, the Education Minister announced that all schools will remain closed until January 2021 due to the pandemic. This statement extends school closures past the previously expected reopening in September. "All schools in Kenya will remain closed until next January because of the coronavirus pandemic. Final year exams, usually taken in October and November, have also been cancelled. Education Minister George Magoha said students would repeat a year as schools had closed in mid-March, three months after the school calendar had begun. But colleges and universities are to reopen in September if they abide by strict guidelines." http://archive.fo/UevkR
C5_Notes: The cessation of movement order that barred entry into and out of Nairobi, Mombasa and Mandera counties lapsed on July 7th. Any movement by public transport vehicles into and out of these areas requires transport providers to first acquire mandatory certification from the Ministry of Health, in consultation with the Ministry of Transport. Users of public or private transport are required to wear a protective mask. https://web.archive.org/web/20200713150952/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C6_Notes: According to the president's address, the cessation of movement into and out of the Nairobi Metropolitan Area, Mombasa County and Mandera County, that is currently in force, shall lapse at 4:00 a.m. on Tuesday, 7th July, 2020. The nationwide curfew from 9pm to 4 am still remains. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210524001445/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/13287760219th%20presidential%20address%20on%20COVID-19%20-%206th%20July,%202020.pdf
C7_Notes: The cessation of movement order that barred entry into and out of Nairobi, Mombasa and Mandera counties lapsed on July 7th. The president also encouraged Kenyans to delay non-essential traveling. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210524001445/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/13287760219th%20presidential%20address%20on%20COVID-19%20-%206th%20July,%202020.pdf
C8_Notes: "International Air Travel into and out of the Territory of the Republic of Kenya shall resume effective 1st August, 2020; in strict conformity with all protocols from the Ministry of Health, local and international civil aviation authorities, and any additional requirements applicable at the ports of departure, arrival or transit" https://web.archive.org/web/20200713145850/https://www.nation.co.ke/kenya/news/covid-19-update-uhuru-full-speech-1445758
H8_Notes: This placeholder mirrors the reality recorded in C6; According to the president's address, the cessation of movement into and out of the Nairobi Metropolitan Area, Mombasa County and Mandera County, that is currently in force, shall lapse at 4:00 a.m. on Tuesday, 7th July, 2020. The nationwide curfew from 9pm to 4 am still remains. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210524001445/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/13287760219th%20presidential%20address%20on%20COVID-19%20-%206th%20July,%202020.pdf

C3_Notes: The restriction on gatherings both social and political is maintained for 30 days till August 5th 2020 from the 7th of July as announced by the president. C4_Notes: The restriction on gatherings both social and political is maintained for 30 days till August 5th 2020 from the 7th of July as announced by the president. C6_Notes: Dusk to dawn curfew extended: "The President did not, however, impose the much-anticipated lockdown, only extending the dusk-to-dawn curfew by another 30 days." http://web.archive.org/web/20200803172523/http://www.mygov.go.ke/index.php?act=article&id=301
H3_Notes: On 27 July, the Ministry of Health announced that contact tracing efforts in the country are still limited. 13461 of the 17975 COVID-19 cases in the country are still pending of contact listing (see pages 10-11). http://web.archive.org/web/20200824163130/https://www.health.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Kenya-COVID-19-SITREP-132-27-Jul-2020.pdf

C1_Notes: I've upgraded the original coding from 2G to 3G. While the initial note indicated that universities may reopen starting Sep 1, I've been unable to find any actual evidence that they did. Instead, universities have largely kicked off the academic year virtually: "With the pandemic having forced the closure of all academic institutions in March, killed more than 500 Kenyans and left more than 30,000 infected, most universities have announced that classes for freshers will begin online next month after the virtual induction. "The pandemic has forced us to come up with different strategy to welcome you to campus virtually. Many have been looking forward to joining the University physically since you did and passed your KCSE 2019," says University of Nairobi Vice-Chancellor Stephen Kiama in a note to the freshers on the university's website. Health protocols "However, Covid-19 pandemic has prevented us to receive you physically in campus but we have to do it virtually. I am confident that very soon you are going to join us and enjoy the ambience of the University and interaction with students, faculty and staff." http://web.archive.org/web/20201125170131/https://allafrica.com/stories/202008240876.html === I've attached the original note below for reference: "Basic educational institutions will reopen January 2021, but University and colleges may open in September 2020 after meeting strict COVID-19 regulations. See: http://web.archive.org/web/20200914023634/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/"
C2_Notes: The president on the 27th of August 2020 announced that the closure of bars is still in effect for the next 30 days. Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210523222331/https://www.president.go.ke/2020/08/26/the-eleventh-11th-presidential-address-on-the-covid-19-pandemic-wednesday-26th-august-2020-state-house-nairobi/
C4_Notes: Note: prohibition against social and political gatherings over 15 people until September 26. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200914023634/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C6_Notes: The night curfew between 9pm and 4am is still in effect. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210523154613/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/200269375410th%20Presidential%20address%20on%20covid-19%20-%2027%20july,%202020.pdf
C7_Notes: According to the US Embassy there are restrictions to internal movement in some areas such as into and out of Nairobi, Mombasa and Mandera counties. Any movement by public transport vehicles into and out of these areas requires transport providers to first acquire mandatory certification from the Ministry of Health, in consultation with the Ministry of Transport. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200914023634/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C8_Notes: International flights commenced since August 1st, 2020 with quarantine measures for all international arrivals. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20200914023634/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
H8_Notes: As reflected in C6, the curfew translates to some measure of protections. Please see: The night curfew between 9pm and 4am is still in effect. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210523154613/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/200269375410th%20Presidential%20address%20on%20covid-19%20-%2027%20july,%202020.pdf

E3_Notes: The President announced the following: One, that the National Treasury considers retaining VAT at 14% until 1st July 2021. Two, that the National Treasury considers retaining the Income Tax Rate (Pay-As-You-Earn) at 25 percent until 1st January 2021. Three, that the National Treasury considers retaining the Resident Income Tax (Corporation Tax) at 25% until 1st January 2021. Four, that to continue cushioning low-income earners the National Treasury maintains the 100 percent tax relief for persons earning a gross monthly income of up to Ksh. 24,000 beyond the Sunset date of 31st December 2020. Five, that to continue cushioning our Micro, Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises the National Treasury considers maintaining the reduction of the current turnover tax rate from 3 percent to 1 percent for all Micro, Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (MSMEs). Six, to enhance access to credit for our micro, small and medium enterprises, the National Treasury is directed to expedite the ongoing roll-out of the credit guarantee scheme in partnership with participating banks as well as our development partners. The credit guarantee scheme as approved by Cabinet is a risk-sharing partnership between the Government and banks, which will afford our enterprises across the country access to credit and increase the amount that we can lend to this sector by an additional 100 billion shillings. Link: https://archive.vn/cyJx3

C1_Notes: "the Ministry of Educationâ€™s announcement that schools in Kenya will reopen from 12 October, starting with Grade 4, Class 8 and Form 4. " https://web.archive.org/web/20201008014834/https://www.unicef.org/kenya/press-releases/UNICEF-welcomes-schools-reopening-in-Kenya
C2_Notes: Bars have been allowed to open by the president. Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210523205446/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/1293258100President%20Uhuru%20Address%20Sep%2028.pdf "The closing time for restaurants, bars and eateries was amended to 10 p.m. on the 29th of September, 2020." https://web.archive.org/web/20201008014524/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C3_Notes: The president's address did not specifically state that this restriction is extended. Also the address in November of 2020 points out that measures were significantly relaxed from the 29th of September and this led to the increase of the infection rate amongst citizens. Hence the reinstating of the measures in a bid to curb the spread of the virus and attempt to control the infection rate. Please see: 4th November https://web.archive.org/web/20210524002105/https://www.president.go.ke/2020/11/04/the-thirteenth-13th-presidential-address-on-the-coronavirus-pandemic-wednesday-4th-november-2020-at-state-house-nairobi/ 28th September https://web.archive.org/web/20210524004335/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/1293258100President%20Uhuru%20Address%20Sep%2028.pdf This article also mentions the resumption of public gatherings as one of the contributing factors to the spike in cases. Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210529112749/https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/19/world/covid-coronavirus
C4_Notes: The indoor gathering should still be at 15 persons although there is no source to back this up. An exception is the religious gathering which can be up to one-third capacity and wedding and funerals have been upgraded to 200 persons from 100. Please see: 28th September https://web.archive.org/web/20210524004335/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/1293258100President%20Uhuru%20Address%20Sep%2028.pdf
C5_Notes: "Users of public or private transport are required to wear a protective mask." https://web.archive.org/web/20201008014524/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C6_Notes: On this day, the new night curfew modification comes into effect and is valid for 60 days according to the president of Kenya in his address. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210523162316/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/1293258100President%20Uhuru%20Address%20Sep%2028.pdf
C7_Notes: According to the US Embassy in Kenya, there are restrictions on intercity or interstate travel. The affected parts remain Nairobi, Mombasa and Mandera counties. Any movement by public transport vehicles into and out of these areas requires transport providers to first acquire mandatory certification from the Ministry of Health, in consultation with the Ministry of Transport." Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201008014524/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C8_Notes: "Domestic air travel resumed on July 15th under Ministry of Health and Transport guidelines. International flights resumed on August 1st." "The test must be conducted and result must be received within 96 hours of arrival. U.S. citizens who do not have such a test may be refused boarding or denied entry to Kenya." https://web.archive.org/web/20201008014524/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
E1_Notes: According to the IMF, there has been social protection (cash transfers and food relief); Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20200929033907/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
H2_Notes: "COVID-19 Testing: Testing is available at the countryâ€™s major hospitals (Aga Khan Hospital, Nairobi Hospital, Kenyatta National Hospital). The charge for the test is approximately USD 100 (KES10,000) at private health facilities and USD50 (KES 5,000) at government hospitals. Test results are available within 48 â€“ 96 hours." https://web.archive.org/web/20201008014524/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
H6_Notes: The government continues to encourage the wearing of face masks. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210524004335/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/1293258100President%20Uhuru%20Address%20Sep%2028.pdf

C2_Notes: Public places, tourism, and hospitality establishments, travel and tour companies, hotels and other accommodations, restaurants, eateries, food and beverage outlets, and entertainment and recreation facilities are allowed to operate, provided they comply with Government of Kenya public health protocols, including 1.5 meter social distancing and the night-time curfew. Bars have been allowed to reopen from 29 September. Link: https://archive.vn/yc3mM
C4_Notes: Places of worship may begin phased re-opening in conformity with applicable guidelines developed by the Inter-Faith Council. The permitted maximum size of religious gatherings is increased to one third (1/3) of its normal sitting capacity. The maximum number of persons permitted to attend funerals and weddings is reviewed upwards to 200, with all in attendance abiding with the Ministry of Health Protocols. Link: https://archive.vn/ZzNkP
C5_Notes: According to the US Embassy in Kenya, users of public or private transport are required to wear a protective mask. Link: https://archive.vn/ZzNkP
C7_Notes: There are restrictions to movement in some parts of the country. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201116132426/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C8_Notes: According to the IMF updates, all international arrivals have to undertake specifically a SarsCoV2 RT PCR Swab test, failure to which they will be quarantined for two weeks. Link: https://archive.vn/Urq8N
E1_Notes: Labour and Social Protection Cabinet Secretary Simon Chelugui has indicated that the cash transfers to poor households will be terminated in the first week of October when funds will dry up. This will end six months of social safeguards to the poor. The government has been sending about Sh1.3 billion every month. Since May, some 341,958 households have received the weekly Sh1,000 stipend to cushion them from the economic hardships caused by the pandemic. Link: https://archive.vn/I9Pc8
E2_Notes: There are no new policies. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201009030538/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
H1_Notes: The Ministry of Health frequently updates COVID-19 information on Twitter. Link: https://archive.vn/r2KZA
H2_Notes: There is no mass testing announced across the country. However, Director of Public Health Dr. Patrick Amoth says the Ministry of Health will soon embark on random testing of COVID-19 in schools. Link: https://archive.vn/BOn1C
H3_Notes: The government abandoned mass testing, focusing instead on symptomatic people and their contacts, and screening vulnerable workers like health service providers and truck drivers. Moreover, the government no longer requires positive patients to be hospitalized but instead encourages them to stay at home. It also stopped covering treatment costs for lower-income families, discouraging many from going to the hospital. Link: https://archive.vn/JJxCz
H6_Notes: The Government of Kenya has directed that face masks must be worn in public places, except when dining, or when adhering to social distancing in hotels, gardens, or on beaches. Link: https://archive.vn/yc3mM
H8_Notes: This is still mirrored by C6. The new night curfew modification comes into effect and is valid for 60 days according to the president of Kenya in his address. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210523162316/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/1293258100President%20Uhuru%20Address%20Sep%2028.pdf

C1_Notes: No change in policy. 3 levels ( Grade 4, Class 8 and Form 4) have reopened since October 12th. https://web.archive.org/web/20201031175617/https://www.unicef.org/kenya/press-releases/UNICEF-welcomes-schools-reopening-in-Kenya
C2_Notes: Public places, tourism and hospitality establishments, travel and tour companies, hotels and other accommodations, restaurants, eateries, food and beverage outlets and entertainment and recreation facilities are allowed to operate, provided they comply with Government of Kenya public health protocols, including 1.5 metre social distancing and the night-time curfew. Kenyan citizens have been advised to avoid crowded places and to work remotely where possible. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201116132652/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C6_Notes: The new night curfew modification comes into effect and is valid for 60 days according to the president of Kenya in his address. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210523162316/https://www.mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/1293258100President%20Uhuru%20Address%20Sep%2028.pdf
C8_Notes: There is no quarantine for travellers from medium risk countries and their list was on the Kenya Civil Aviation's website although there is a need for a negative test result obtained in the last 96 hours. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210524065549/https://www.kcaa.or.ke/protocol-for-air-travel-operations The list can be found here; https://web.archive.org/web/20200928174751/https://www.kcaa.or.ke/sites/default/files/docs/covid_19/Min-of-Transport-33x3-1-8-20.pdf
H1_Notes: Daily updates posted on Kenya's Ministry of Health page. Example: https://web.archive.org/web/20201031180659/https://www.health.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/NERC-MOH-CS-Covid-Release-20102020-.pdf
H2_Notes: Government keeps increasing testing capacity. Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210524170642/https://www.health.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/NERC-MOH-CS-Covid-Release-20102020-.pdf
H3_Notes: The government abandoned mass testing, focusing instead on symptomatic people and their contacts, and screening vulnerable workers like health service providers and truck drivers. Moreover, the government no longer requires positive patients to be hospitalized but instead encourages them to stay at home. It also stopped covering treatment costs for lower-income families, discouraging many from going to the hospital. Link: https://archive.vn/JJxCz
H6_Notes: The Government of Kenya has directed that face masks must be worn in public places, except when dining, or when adhering to social distancing in hotels, gardens, or on beaches. Link: https://archive.vn/yc3mM

C2_Notes: Due to change in curfew hours, all bars, restaurants, and other establishments open to the public must now close by 9.00 pm Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201116133747/https://mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/26505742President%20Uhuru%20Speech%20Nov%204,%202020.pdf
C6_Notes: Curfew hours were extended, they now run from 10pm to 4am local time. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201116133747/https://mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/26505742President%20Uhuru%20Speech%20Nov%204,%202020.pdf
H8_Notes: Curfew hours were extended, they now run from 10pm to 4am local time. This also translates to some form of protections for the elderly. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201116133747/https://mygov.go.ke/administration/archive/notices/26505742President%20Uhuru%20Speech%20Nov%204,%202020.pdf

C1_Notes: No change. Some grade levels â€“ Examination Classes â€“ have resumed in person learning under heightened health safety measures. All other basic learning classes plan to resume in person January 2021. University and colleges opened in September 2020 after meeting strict COVID-19 regulations. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201123160715/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C2_Notes: No change. Public places, tourism and hospitality establishments, travel and tour companies, hotels and other accommodations, restaurants, eateries, food and beverage outlets and entertainment and recreation facilities are allowed to operate, provided they comply with Government of Kenya public health protocols, including 1.5 metre social distancing and the night-time curfew. Kenyan citizens have been advised to work from home when possible. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201123160933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C3_Notes: No change. On the 28th of September, the Government of Kenya stated that large gatherings, meetings, conferences and political events over 15 people remain suspended. All political gatherings and rallies are suspended until January 3, 2020 There is an exception for places of worship, and weddings and funerals: Places of worship may begin phased re-opening in conformity with applicable guidelines developed by the Inter-Faith Council. The permitted maximum size of religious gatherings is increased to one third (1/3) of its normal sitting capacity. The maximum number of persons permitted to attend funerals and weddings is reviewed upwards to 200, with all in attendance abiding with Ministry of Health Protocols. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201123160715/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C4_Notes: On the 4th of November 2020 due to the increase in the number of cases, the president had to reinstate the suspension of social and political gatherings. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210524002105/https://www.president.go.ke/2020/11/04/the-thirteenth-13th-presidential-address-on-the-coronavirus-pandemic-wednesday-4th-november-2020-at-state-house-nairobi/
C5_Notes: Public transportation is operating. Users of public and private transportation are required to wear a mask. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201123160715/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C6_Notes: No change. Nightly curfew hours are from 10:00 pm to 4:00 am, in effect up to January 3rd, 2021. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201123160715/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C8_Notes: No change. All passengers arriving an transiting Kenya must have a PCR Covid-19 negative certificate for a test conducted 96 hours prior to travel. There is no inland border crossings except for commercial trucks. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201123160715/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
H1_Notes: Regular updates and videos posted by Ministry of Health. Text based public information campaign in place for people showing symptoms. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201123161208/https://www.health.go.ke/

C1_Notes: No change. Schools are open for Grade 4, Class 8 and Form 4 (as of October 12) Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130145249/https://www.unicef.org/kenya/press-releases/UNICEF-welcomes-schools-reopening-in-Kenya
C2_Notes: Public places, tourism and hospitality establishments, travel and tour companies, hotels and other accommodations, restaurants, eateries, food and beverage outlets and entertainment and recreation facilities are allowed to operate, provided they comply with Government of Kenya public health protocols, including 1.5 metre social distancing and the night-time curfew. Eateries and restaurants must close at 9pm (local time). Kenyan citizens have been advised to avoid crowded places and to work remotely where possible. Pharmacies and other shops selling essential products remain open, though business hours may be affected by the nationwide curfew. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130145110/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C3_Notes: No change. Large gatherings, meetings, conferences and political events over 15 people remain suspended. All political gatherings and rallies are suspended until January 3, 2020. Places of worship may begin phased re-opening in conformity with applicable guidelines developed by the Inter-Faith Council. The permitted maximum size of religious gatherings is increased to one third (1/3) of its normal sitting capacity. The maximum number of persons permitted to attend funerals and weddings is reviewed upwards to 200, with all in attendance abiding with Ministry of Health Protocols. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130144817/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C4_Notes: On the 4th of November 2020 due to the increase in the number of cases, the president had to reinstate the suspension of social and political gatherings. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210524002105/https://www.president.go.ke/2020/11/04/the-thirteenth-13th-presidential-address-on-the-coronavirus-pandemic-wednesday-4th-november-2020-at-state-house-nairobi/
C6_Notes: No change. There is a curfew in place, during which everyone must stay at home or indoors. Nightly curfew hours are from 10:00 pm to 4:00 am, in effect up to January 3rd, 2021. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130145110/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C8_Notes: All passengers arriving an transiting Kenya must have a PCR Covid-19 negative certificate for a test conducted 96 hours prior to travel. There is no inland border crossings except for commercial trucks. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130144817/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
H1_Notes: Regular updates and informational materials provided by the ministry of health. Text base information campaign for symptomatic individuals is available. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130151118/https://www.health.go.ke/
H2_Notes: No change. Tests are prioritised for those who show symptoms and have been in contact with a known COVID-19 case, health care workers showing symptoms, health care workers in contact with a known case without PPE, all close household contacts of confirmed cases, all trans-border and long distance truck drivers, all prison remandees and vulnerable individuals in settings with community transmission. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130151230/https://www.health.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Targeted-Testing-Strategy-for-COVID-19-in-Kenya.pdf
H3_Notes: The government continues to closely monitor the home based programs and the cases. Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210524173347/https://www.health.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/November-24-Covid-19-Statement.pdf

E2_Notes: National Treasury Cabinet Secretary Ukur Yatani issued a statement saying that from January 1st 2021 corporate tax, individual income tax and VAT will return to their pre pandemic levels (increasing from 25% to 30%, 25% to 30% and 14% to 16% respectively). Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201207143941/https://treasury.go.ke/media-centre/general-press-releases.html
E3_Notes: President Uhuru Kenyatta launched the County Governments post-COVID-19 socioeconomic recovery strategy on Friday Dec 4th. The 132 billion KES plan prioritises agriculture, water and sanitization, urban development and housing, transport, tourism, health, education, social protection, and gender and youth as anchor sectors and will last 3 years. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201207143334/https://www.president.go.ke/2020/12/04/president-kenyatta-launches-county-governments-post-covid-recovery-strategy/

C1_Notes: According to the Uk Government's website on travel to Kenya, The following counties; Nairobi, Kajiado, Kiambu, Machakos and Nakuru, have the schools shut down except for those writing exams and the ones in medical school. Please see: https://archive.vn/fc0R8 Furthermore, Eyewitness News backs this up. "Kenya is gripped by a deadly third wave of the pandemic but nearly three-quarters of all cases have been recorded in the capital Nairobi and the nearby counties of Nairobi, Kajiado, Kiambu, Machakos and Nakuru. Also see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210704091455/https://ewn.co.za/2021/03/26/kenya-imposes-nairobi-lockdown-shuts-schools-to-contain-covid-19
C2_Notes: According to the UK government's website on travel to Kenya, Public places, tourism and hospitality establishments, travel and tour companies, hotels and other accommodations, and recreation facilities are allowed to operate, provided they comply with Government of Kenya public health protocols, including 1.5 metre social distancing and the night-time curfew. On 26 March 2021, the Government of Kenya confirmed that bars in the counties of Nairobi, Machakos, Kajiado, Kiambu and Nakuru are closed and that eateries and restaurants in the same counties will provide takeaways services only and will not serve alcohol. Bars, restaurants and eateries in all other counties would continue to close at 9pm (local time), but will be permitted to sell alcohol. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411174349/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C3_Notes: According to the UK government's website on travel to Kenya, the mass gatherings of all kinds are cancelled. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411174349/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C5_Notes: According to the UK government's website on travel to Kenya, The Government of Kenya has directed that, in addition to public transport systems, social distancing rules â€“ in the form of capacity restrictions â€“ will also apply when using private vehicles, including taxis. This means five-seater vehicles will only be allowed to carry two passengers in addition to the driver, while seven-seater vehicles will only be allowed four passengers in addition to the driver. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411174349/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C6_Notes: According to the UK government's website on travel to Kenya, for Nairobi, Machakos, Kajiado, Kiambu and Nakuru, the curfew will be in effect from 8pm to 4am (local time) until further notice. The rest of Kenya will observe curfew from 10pm to 4am (local time). During curfew hours, everyone must stay at home or indoors, except for essential service workers. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411174349/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C7_Notes: According to the Kenya government's Ministry of Health's Twitter account, on the 26th of March 2021, President Uhuru Kenyatta has announced cessation of all movement by road, rail, or air into and out of Nairobi, Kajiado, Machakos, Kiambu and Nakuru, effective Midnight. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411182112/https://twitter.com/MOH_Kenya/status/1375436477853753344
C8_Notes: According to the UK government's website on travel to Kenya, all passengers coming to Kenya from the UK require a valid COVID-19 vaccination certificate and a COVID-19 negative PCR test and must self-isolate on arrival for 7 days. All UK citizens and residents travelling to Kenya from the UK via any route who have a valid COVID-19 PCR test, but do not have a valid COVID-19 vaccination certificate, will be subject to 14 days mandatory quarantine on arrival at a Government of Kenya facility at their own cost. All travellers under the age of 18 will only require a certificate of COVID-19 negative PCR test to enter Kenya. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411183025/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/entry-requirements
E1_Notes: According to the IMF, last year's budget made provision for food relief and cash transfers but there is no confirmation to what extent and if these measures are still in place. For reference, please see: https://archive.ph/gxVRM
E2_Notes: According to the IMF, A package of tax measures has been adopted, including full income tax relief for persons earning below the equivalent of $225 per month, reduction of the top pay-as you earn rate from 30 to 25 percent, reduction of the base corporate income tax rate from 30 to 25 percent, reduction of the turnover tax rate on small businesses from 3 to 1 percent, and a reduction of the standard VAT rate from 16 to 14 percent. Some of the tax measures, including the reduction of top PAYE rate, corporate income tax rate and VAT were reversed effective January 1, 2021. Please see: https://archive.ph/gxVRM
E3_Notes: There is no new announcement on spending for COVID-19 for the country. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411195401/https://twitter.com/StateHouseKenya/status/1377658196626653184
E4_Notes: The country did not donate to the international community at this time on COVID but donated 45,000 Kenyan made gadgets to Botswana, South Sudan, Mauritius, Sierra Leone and Namibia to help them undertake their census. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411195401/https://twitter.com/StateHouseKenya/status/1377658196626653184
H1_Notes: The Ministry of Health has an active twitter handle that provides the updates on the virus. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411202046/https://twitter.com/MOH_Kenya
H2_Notes: There are tests run to ensure the positivity rate reduces. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411210309/https://twitter.com/MOH_Kenya/status/1379811038166716417
H3_Notes: Information from the Ministry of Health establishes that 98% of the cases are from local transmission. This can imply confirmation through contact tracing. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411202439/https://twitter.com/MOH_Kenya/status/1377288922565328904
H4_Notes: There is no new data for this placeholder. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411205830/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/kenya-receives-1-million-vaccines-from-covax-1.5331437
H5_Notes: There is no new information on spending for vaccines. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411205830/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/kenya-receives-1-million-vaccines-from-covax-1.5331437
H6_Notes: According to the UK government's website on travel to Kenya, masks are mandatory in public. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411174349/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
H7_Notes: AstraZeneca A,C The first phase targets frontline health workers & those in critical services such as our security personnel, police, military as well as teachers. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407161340/https://twitter.com/MOH_Kenya/status/1377292318542290952 Also see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411204850/https://twitter.com/MOH_Kenya/status/1378323424997748736/photo/1
H8_Notes: The curfew in the country is still in effect. Please see: Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411174349/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus

C1_Notes: Schools are to reopen for all years apart from Grade 4 at the start of the third school term. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083408/https://twitter.com/EduMinKenya/status/1390629235505745923
C2_Notes: On 1 May 2021, the Government of Kenya confirmed that restaurants and eateries in the counties of Nairobi, Machakos, Kajiado, Kiambu and Nakuru would reopen to customers, provided they comply with Government of Kenya public health protocols. Bars...pharmacies and other shops selling essential products remain open, though business hours may be affected by the nationwide curfew. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083746/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C3_Notes: Across Kenya, the maximum number of persons permitted to attend meetings or events has been capped at 15, permitted to attend funerals has been capped at 50, weddings capped at 30, with all in attendance expected to abide by Ministry of Health protocols. Political gatherings have been suspended until otherwise directed Kenyan citizens have been advised to avoid crowded places and to work remotely where possible. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083746/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C4_Notes: Across Kenya, the maximum number of persons permitted to attend meetings or events has been capped at 15, permitted to attend funerals has been capped at 50, weddings capped at 30. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083746/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C5_Notes: According to the UK government's website on travel to Kenya, apart from wearing masks, "The Government of Kenya has directed that, in addition to public transport systems, social distancing rules â€“ in the form of capacity restrictions â€“ will also apply when using private vehicles, including taxis. This means five-seater vehicles will only be allowed to carry two passengers in addition to the driver, while seven-seater vehicles will only be allowed four passengers in addition to the driver." This reflects reduced capacity. Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210511083746/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus Also see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210529100114/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C6_Notes: Is a curfew in place? Yes Curfew is from 10pm to 4 am. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511084133/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C7_Notes: Under the restrictions now being relaxed, Nairobi and surrounding counties were treated as one zone, with residents barred from traveling to other areas. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083449/https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/kenyan-president-lifts-covid-19-lockdown-imposed-last-month-2021-05-01/
C8_Notes: Travellers from Brunei, Kuwait, Thailand, Pakistan and the Czech Republic are required to undergo 14 days of mandatory qurantine; All passenger flights, whether commercial or charter, between Kenya and the UK are suspended, all passengers coming to Kenya from United Kingdom must have avalid COVID-19 vaccination certificate and a COVID-19 negative PCR test and must self-isolate on arrival for a period of seven days. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511084855/https://kcaa.or.ke/sites/default/files/docs/covid_19/exempted_states.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20210411183025/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/entry-requirements
H8_Notes: According to the US Embassy in Kenya, there is a curfew from 10pm to 4 am for the entire country. This translates to some measure of protections for the elderly. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210511084133/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

C1_Notes: Schools are to reopen for all years apart from Grade 4 at the start of the third school term. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083408/https://twitter.com/EduMinKenya/status/1390629235505745923
C2_Notes: On 1 May 2021, the Government of Kenya confirmed that restaurants and eateries in the counties of Nairobi, Machakos, Kajiado, Kiambu and Nakuru would reopen to customers, provided they comply with Government of Kenya public health protocols. Bars...pharmacies and other shops selling essential products remain open, though business hours may be affected by the nationwide curfew. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083746/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C3_Notes: Across Kenya, the maximum number of persons permitted to attend meetings or events has been capped at 15, permitted to attend funerals has been capped at 50, weddings capped at 30, with all in attendance expected to abide by Ministry of Health protocols. Political gatherings have been suspended until otherwise directed Kenyan citizens have been advised to avoid crowded places and to work remotely where possible. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083746/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C4_Notes: Across Kenya, the maximum number of persons permitted to attend meetings or events has been capped at 15, permitted to attend funerals has been capped at 50, weddings capped at 30. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083746/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/coronavirus
C5_Notes: Individuals using public or private transport are required to wear a protective mask. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511084133/https://ke.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
C7_Notes: Under the restrictions now being relaxed, Nairobi and surrounding counties were treated as one zone, with residents barred from traveling to other areas. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511083449/https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/kenyan-president-lifts-covid-19-lockdown-imposed-last-month-2021-05-01/
C8_Notes: Travellers from Brunei, Kuwait, Thailand, Pakistan and the Czech Republic are required to undergo 14 days of mandatory qurantine; All passenger flights, whether commercial or charter, between Kenya and the UK are suspended, all passengers coming to Kenya from United Kingdom must have avalid COVID-19 vaccination certificate and a COVID-19 negative PCR test and must self-isolate on arrival for a period of seven days. https://web.archive.org/web/20210511084855/https://kcaa.or.ke/sites/default/files/docs/covid_19/exempted_states.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20210411183025/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kenya/entry-requirements
